story.text_en: When news of Oersted's discovery reached Paris in 1820, AmpÃ¨re sprang into action. Within a week, he made a stunning discovery: you don't need a magnet to create magnetic force; two *current-carrying wires* will interact. If currents flow in the same direction, they attract; if opposite, they repel. This was a huge leapâ€”he proved magnetism could be generated entirely by *electricity*. He theorized further: if you coil a wire (a solenoid), it acts like a magnet. Perhaps Earth's own magnetism is caused by currents circulating deep inside. His 1826 memoir formalized these ideas with rigorous calculus, achieving a 'Newtonian' synthesis of electromagnetism.

fun_facts.text_en: In his honor, the SI base unit of 'electric current' is named the 'Ampere' (A).

AmpÃ¨re proposed the 'molecular current hypothesis': magnets don't have 'magnetic charge', but are made of tiny, looping currents inside the molecules. This genius guess was confirmed by modern quantum mechanics (electron spin).

simple_explanation.text_en:
Oersted said, 'A wire can move a compass.'
AmpÃ¨re asked, 'What happens between two wires?'
He tested it: put two wires parallel. When electricity flows in the *same* direction, the wires *hug* each other (attract). When it flows in *opposite* directions, they *push apart* (repel).
AmpÃ¨re concluded: There is no special 'magnet stuff'. All magnetism is just what happens when 'electricity moves'.
